attributes.title: Figure 8 In Taxonomic Review Of The Rare Mexican Snake Genus Chersodromus (Serpentes: Dipsadidae), With The Description Of Two New Species

attributes.title: Figure 2 In Who Is The Red-Bearded Snake, Anyway? Clarifying The Taxonomic Status Of Chironius Pyrrhopogon (Wied, 1824) (Serpentes: Colubridae)
attributes.description: FIGURE 2. Direct records of Chironius exoletus (squares) and C. pyrrhopogon following institutional identifications attributed to specialists (white circles), and indirect records of C. pyrrhopogon recovered in the catalogues of the Instituto Butantan (black circles), the black star represents the type-locality of C. pyrrhopogon (Wied, 1824). Specimens of Instituto Butantan were destroyed by fire on May 15 th of 2010.

attributes.title: Suculentophichthus Nasus, A New Genus And New Species Of Snake Eel From The Northern Gulf Of Aqaba, Red Sea (Teleostei: Ophichthidae)
attributes.description: A new genus and species of snake eel, Suculentophichthus nasus, is described on the basis of a single specimen collected with a beach seine in 0.5–1 m depth at the northern beach of Eilat, Israel, Gulf of Aqaba, Red Sea. The new genus is characterised within the subfamily Ophichthinae by the tail which is much longer than the head and trunk; median fins low; origin of dorsal fin well in advance of pectoral-fin base; lower part of pectoral-fin base arising opposite upper one-fourth of gill opening, and occupying the upper one third of gill opening; gill openings sublateral, elongate, nearly vertical and crescentic, shorter than isthmus; eye moderately developed, its center above posterior third of upper jaw, its posterior margin well in advance of rictus; jaws moderately developed, lower jaw fits into upper jaw; snout conical, tapering evenly, its tip rounded; underside of snout with a median sulcus exposing the teeth in advance of the anterior nostril bases; anterior nostrils within short tubes; a large, succulent-leaf shaped flap behind anterior nostril; posterior nostril a hole above upper lip; teeth conical, erect, numerous, and small, anteriorly biserial and posteriorly uniserial on maxillary and biserial on mandible; a series of 6 vomerine teeth; and two preopercular pores. The new species is compared with other species of the subfamily and a key to the ophichthine eels of the Red Sea is presented.

attributes.title: Suculentophichthus Nasus, A New Genus And New Species Of Snake Eel From The Northern Gulf Of Aqaba, Red Sea (Teleostei: Ophichthidae)
attributes.description: A new genus and species of snake eel, Suculentophichthus nasus, is described on the basis of a single specimen collected with a beach seine in 0.5–1 m depth at the northern beach of Eilat, Israel, Gulf of Aqaba, Red Sea. The new genus is characterised within the subfamily Ophichthinae by the tail which is much longer than the head and trunk; median fins low; origin of dorsal fin well in advance of pectoral-fin base; lower part of pectoral-fin base arising opposite upper one-fourth of gill opening, and occupying the upper one third of gill opening; gill openings sublateral, elongate, nearly vertical and crescentic, shorter than isthmus; eye moderately developed, its center above posterior third of upper jaw, its posterior margin well in advance of rictus; jaws moderately developed, lower jaw fits into upper jaw; snout conical, tapering evenly, its tip rounded; underside of snout with a median sulcus exposing the teeth in advance of the anterior nostril bases; anterior nostrils within short tubes; a large, succulent-leaf shaped flap behind anterior nostril; posterior nostril a hole above upper lip; teeth conical, erect, numerous, and small, anteriorly biserial and posteriorly uniserial on maxillary and biserial on mandible; a series of 6 vomerine teeth; and two preopercular pores. The new species is compared with other species of the subfamily and a key to the ophichthine eels of the Red Sea is presented.

attributes.title: Figure 1 In A New Subspecies Of Short-Toed Snake-Eagle From Wallacea Determined From Morphological And Dna Comparison
attributes.description: FIGURE 1. Maximum Likelihood (ML) tree showing placement of the Timor individual of C. gallicus within the Circaetus clade, with H.novaeguineae used as the outgroup. Maximum Parsimony (MP), ML, and Bayesian inference methods produce the same consensus tree. Node labels sequentially represent branch support values for the ML, Bayesian, and MP trees, respectively, with only bootstrap/posterior probabilities greater than 80/0.8 shown. Branch lengths indicate percent divergence, with the scale bar corresponding to 2% divergence. The Timor individual clusters with Palearctic C. gallicus from Israel and France with high bootstrap and posterior probability values, indicating about 0.4% divergence.

attributes.title: Figure 1 In A New Subspecies Of Short-Toed Snake-Eagle From Wallacea Determined From Morphological And Dna Comparison
attributes.description: FIGURE 1. Maximum Likelihood (ML) tree showing placement of the Timor individual of C. gallicus within the Circaetus clade, with H.novaeguineae used as the outgroup. Maximum Parsimony (MP), ML, and Bayesian inference methods produce the same consensus tree. Node labels sequentially represent branch support values for the ML, Bayesian, and MP trees, respectively, with only bootstrap/posterior probabilities greater than 80/0.8 shown. Branch lengths indicate percent divergence, with the scale bar corresponding to 2% divergence. The Timor individual clusters with Palearctic C. gallicus from Israel and France with high bootstrap and posterior probability values, indicating about 0.4% divergence.

attributes.title: Figure 2 In A New Subspecies Of Short-Toed Snake-Eagle From Wallacea Determined From Morphological And Dna Comparison
attributes.description: FIGURE 2. Boxplots of wingspan and tail lengths across both sexes in Lesser Sundas Short-toed Snake-eagle populations as compared to Palearctic populations. The boxes mark out the 25th–75th percentiles. Palearctic birds are consistently larger than individualsfrom the Lesser Sundas.Additionally, in Palearctic populations females arelarger thanmales,whereas in the Lesser Sundas populations, female-biased dimorphism is absent, both sexes being of similar size.
